content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 24:21, “And the man, wondering at her, remained silent so as to know whether the Lord had made his journey prosperous or not”

I have been allowed an awesome opportunity not only to minister to big groups but also one on one. I find that what someone needs is most likely what I also need. In the process of encouraging them, I also get encouraged. I get a new understanding of a scripture and often time God allows me to develop a word out of it.

One of one favorite subjects to speak on is Prayer. I find a good flow as I do it. It is my strength, it builds my faith. I am more stronger in praying than I am in the word. I find it much easier to pray than read my bible. Now we know that praying is not a one way but two ways. It’s easy to talk to God but hard to wait and hear what He has to say. I envy those people who stand to say the Lord spoke to them. God speaks to people differently, some through visions, dreams, through someone else, through His words, through signs and wonders. I don’t know how the Lord does speak to you but I am yet to hear the Lord speak to me audibly. I can sense when He is speaking to me at times when he drops a word in my spirit or when he drops a thought. When I begin to ponder on it, the more I get revelation the more I can tell He is speaking to me. This is one of the ways He speaks to me. What happens when you have prayed for something over and over again and all you are waiting is to hear God speak to you maybe audibly over what to do about the situation? I will share a concept from a passage that has been a blessing to me over the years.

Genesis 24 has really taught me so much about praying and waiting to hear what the Lord has to say. In this case, it’s not about what the Lord said but what the Lord did. The message was not in what He spoke but what He did. The reason why the person in the picture knew it was God is because He had prayed SPECIFICALLY for something. Abraham’s servant was given a task to find a wife for Isaac. He had been given guidelines as where he should find her from. He has no description of what to look for but he applies wisdom of God’s will for a good wife. He SPECIFICALLY prays to God about those qualities. “The lips of the righteous knows what is acceptable” Proverbs 10:32 tells me. Staying in the word will teach you more of what God’s will is for mankind, there after when we know what the boundaries are, we pray within those boundaries (guidelines). The train finds complete freedom to flow within the boundaries it’s given and so is a righteous man who knows the boundaries of what is accepted. Praying within boundaries is not an indication that you will get all you’ve prayed but allowing the God of the boundaries to exercise His will for YOUR life in that which you have prayed for. God’s word is “THE WILL” for ALL but when you pray the will, He sees out of the total WILL what He desires for you to have at a given time and does it. Here is where we many times we struggle, waiting patiently for the will to manifest in God’s way.

The servant prayed God’s will, finished praying and started watching to see what the Lord would do. Here comes Rebekah, who does everything he had prayed to God for, Genesis 24:21, “And the man, wondering at her, remained silent so as to know whether the Lord had made his journey prosperous or not“. Can you see he wasn’t waiting for God to send thunder, angel to speak to him or God Himself appear and say, “Servant, I have heard your prayer and now I have come to perform”. For this man, all the speaking he needed was to see what He had prayed being fulfilled. Watch this, when he saw all that he prayed coming true, he did not jump and conclude. He sat patiently to see if the Lord had prospered his way or not. The only reason he finally knew it was God’s will was, he had peace within, he did not struggle or fight for it, no one else came for comparison, and there is no indication that he moved to another place. When I have prayed for something within the boundaries for a long time, I cease to pray so as to see what I have prayed. Ceasing to pray and watching does not mean I gave up it means that I activated the will and now it’s time to watch it’s manifestation in silence. I believe the people who never pray specifically have a way of missing God’s will, why? because you could be praying and praying and God is doing something but you can’t see as you won’t know. You could be waiting for God to speak to you in another way more so audibly and miss what He was doing to show He was speaking. See what you prayed, to continue.. Blessings Evans

Thanks
Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Samuel 17:46, “THIS DAY the Lord will deliver you into my hand, and I will strike you and take your head from you… that all the earth may know that there is a God in Israel”

There is something about “THIS DAY (TODAY)”, which is present tense that has to be addressed otherwise we start dwelling on either yesterday which is past tense or think of tomorrow which is future tense. God has given us today to make good use as we live one day at a time. There is a song we used to sing, “One day at a time sweet Jesus, that’s all I’m asking from you, just give me strength to do everyday what I have do, yesterday is gone sweet Jesus, and tomorrow may never be mine, Lord help me today, show me the way one day at a time”.

Over and over again the bible addresses today, Jesus said, “do not worry about tomorrow for tomorrow will take care of itself” in other words, deal with what you have today, what has already been supplied. Worrying about tomorrow or something that has not happened yet is not healthy for there is a possibility of wasting today. Today’s wasted can never be recovered, for time is precious. I’m learning most of these the hard way. “Choose ye this day whom you will serve”.

There are things we need to do that many times we neglect them thinking that we have a lot of time to do them another day. This is where the word procrastination comes in. Procrastination is to postpone or delay needlessly, to put off doing something, especially out of habitual carelessness or laziness. Someone said, procrastination is the thief of time to which I am a victim. Procrastination becomes very serious when something of priority is neglected for example, there are people reading this who have not repented of their sins and put their trust in Jesus Christ alone for their eternal salvation. They are still procrastinating with an idea, “I have a lot of time to one day do it”. If tomorrow is promised to no one, today is your day of salvation. Salvation should be a priority because the day of the Lord is approaching.

To put this to perspective, let’s look at David facing Goliath. For 40 days the Israelites under the leadership of Saul had been threatened and constantly postponed or delayed their attack, later David comes into the scene and sees an opportunity to do something for there was a man who was blaspheming the name of the Living God. Remember David was not suppose to be here, he was not a warrior at this point, had no training or weapons, and had no army to back him up yet he is not even looking for time to go and train, build up an army and get his weapons. He understands that if he is going to fight, it’s either now or never. 1Samuel 17:46, “This day the Lord will deliver you into my hand, and I will strike you and take your head from you… that all the earth may know that there is a God in Israel”. This day, today, this hour I got to deal with this. As he is saying “this day”, he has God in mind to help him overcome this day. I have so many Goliaths I have been delaying fighting because of the fear just like Saul and his people. I don’t want to postpone them for tomorrow or another day, I want to face them today. You can tell that they did not mention the name of the Lord in their situation therefore for 40 days, they were afraid of facing one man. David comes to win not tomorrow but today. Not only is he planning on winning today, he has a strategy of doing it, one, the Lord will deliver you in my hands; two, I will strike you and take your head from you; three, my reason for doing this is to let the whole earth know that there is a God in Israel. Imagine the time lost (40 days), they could have used that time to do better things if they had David’s spirit and strategy.

Procrastination is a condition we have to deal with, certain moves and decisions to be made, things to accomplish. Delaying them more may not help resolve them. Postponing paying bills, certain duties and tasks, certain responsibilities is not healthy. Let’s all begin to identify things we have been putting aside that we need to deal with, face, fight and say like David, “This day the Lord will deliver you into my hand”. The Lord is giving us grace to deal with this day, check this out, Exodus 32:29, For Moses had said, consecrate yourselves today to the Lord, even every man upon his son, and upon his brother; that he may bestow upon you blessings this day”, Deuteronomy 11:26, “Behold, I set before you this day a blessing and a curse”. If the Lord is mostly talking about this day, we too can live one day at a time dealing with things we have been postponing for so long.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Oil In The Lamp, by Sarah Susan

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“The Lord said to Moses “Command the Israelites to bring you clear oil of pressed olives for the light so that the lamps may be kept burning continually” Leviticus 24: 1,2

What is clear oil ??From where it has to be derived -olives ?? Olive has a special significance in the Bible…The oil can be extracted only this olive is pressed rather crushed /squeezed.. This olive undergoes painful treatment for the core essence to get extracted , which in turn becomes the source of nourishment for many.. This oil has to be used in the lamps so that they give light and can be kept burning continually

Our Lord Jesus was crushed on the cruel cross of Calvary ..Why? Isaiah answers according to Isaiah 53 “But he was pierced for our transgressions and crushed for our iniquities” Yes the precious blood shed by our dear Lord is the only source for our lamps to keep burning till the end .. Not just few drops of oil, but it needs to be poured substantially …His blood was poured out for you and me …A lamp is only an article in which oil should be poured in order to give light…..,Without this oil, it cannot serve the very purpose …The blood of Jesus, the author and perfecter of our faith symbolizes the clear oil of pressed olives referred above

Mathew 25 speaks about ten virgins who took their lamps and went out to meet the bridegroom. Five of them were foolish and five of them were wise. The foolish ones took their lamps with them but not the oil whereas the wise ones took oil in jars along with their lamps ….Since the bridegroom was a longtime in coming, and they all became drowsy and fell asleep. At midnight the cry rang out “Here is the bride groom Come out to meet him” Then all the virgins woke up and trimmed their lamps. But the foolish ones realized only then that their lamps were going out because of lack of oil ..Meanwhile before they could go and buy some oil, the bridegroom arrived and the wise could go with him to the wedding banquet and then the door was shut, thus the foolish ones could not reach…Be it a bedside light or a street light or a lantern or a table lamp or a reading light or desk lamp or floor lamp , without fuel in it, it is useless…
Importance of oil in the lamps is well demonstrated here ..

Yes the lamp is useful only when sufficient oil is poured into it.. Let us be like the wise virgins who realized the importance of oil, in their lamps to be kept burning continually …How does a person become wise ? Let us learn the way since it is mentioned in the above parable that wise virgins could meet the bridegroom and were invited to the wedding banquet …And after they could enter, the door was shut and not opened for the foolish .. “The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom and the knowledge of the Holy one is understanding ” ..Well, God leads us till the end.. He never leaves us or forsake us in the middle of this life’s journey …He is ALL SUFFICIENT. Our lamps need to give light CONTINUALLY ,as mentioned to the Israelites …Consistency is one of the most characteristics of a believer. In spiritual terms, this moment a person cannot be on a mountain level and the very next moment fall to the ground level…

Our lamps need to filled with oil from above …in order to give light in a continuous/ constant/ non stop/ unbroken/ permanent way .. David was at great spiritual heights but his lamp could not give light for a season due to a break caused by desires of the flesh.. Joseph ‘s lamp was burning continually though he was put to the tests of lust , prison and distance from near and dear ! Are our lamps giving light without breaks/stops ?

Light is meant for this dark world ….Isaiah prophesied about the birth of Lord Jesus in Isa 9:2 “The people walking in darkness have seen a great light , on those living in the land of shadow of death, a light has dawned”

Jesus is the light of the world .. .The real light. and the.light forever…We as His children need to reflect his light as long as we have breathe ..! Are we the light to this world or are we allowing the darkness in this world to enter into us , thus putting off the light ? ? Mathews 5:14 “You are the light of the world. “A city on a hill cannot be hidden. Neither do people light a lamp and put it under a bowl. Instead they put it on its stand, and it gives light to everyone in the house. In the same way, let your light shine before men, that they may see your good deeds and praise your Father in heaven”

Are we hiding the light under a bowl ?What does this bowl signify ? Some tend to pretend as if they do not know the Lord …Are our job/profession/career/ family/ culture /friendship /prestige not allowing our light to shine ?Are they making our light to be put under a bowl ?Let us examine ourselves…Nowadays people are denying his name for some worldly benefits .. “For God who said “Let light shine out of darkness” made his light shine in our hearts to give us the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Christ ” 2Cor 4 : 6 “”Those who are wise will shine like the brightness of the heavens and those who lead many to the righteousness like the stars for ever and ever” Daniel 12 : 3

Yes if we resist the devil and shine out of the darkness, we will all inherit the eternal home where the Lamb is its lamp “The city does not need the sun or moon to shine on it for the glory of the God gives it light and the lamb is its lamp. The nations will walk by its LIGHT and the kings of the earth will bring their splendor into it.” Rev 21: 24 “There will be no more night. They will not need the light of a lamp or the light of the sun, for the Lord God will give them light and they will reign forever and ever” Rev 22:5

We are indeed privileged to be invited to the greatest beautiful city ,which words cannot describe and we will be with the Lord forever and ever

“The light of the righteous shines brightly but the lamp of the wicked is snuffed out” Proverbs 13 : 9 May the brilliance of the light from heaven, which flashed around Paul and transformed him from a persecutor to a preacher also flash on us to transform us to meet the Lord in the air… by Sarah Susan

title.rendered: Beware of False Teachers (Part 3) by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

3﻿ Beloved, while I was very diligent to write to you ﻿﻿concerning our common salvation, I found it necessary to write to you exhorting ﻿you to contend earnestly for the faith which was once for all delivered to the saints. ﻿4﻿ For certain men have crept in unnoticed, who long ago were marked out for this condemnation, ungodly men, who turn the grace of our God into lewdness and deny the only Lord ﻿2﻿God and our Lord Jesus Christ. (Jude 3 – 4)

When one looks throughout the Scriptures and even in our world today, there is constant fighting, contending for land, possessions, property, status, etc…. Jude tells us that we need to CONTEND EARNESTLY for the faith. To do something earnestly is to be intense and serious in one’s mentality regarding the matter at hand. Is there any matter greater than the Gospel? Proverbs 28:1 reminds us, “…the righteous are as bold as a lion.” The lion is known for its boldness, for its roar, for its presence. Should not the Christian be bold in his or her witness in the midst of false teachers? In part 2 we examined the difference between someone being in error and someone being classified as a heretic. Carlton Pearson, is a well know preacher, yet denies the existence of Hell, TD Jakes does not believe in the trinity. We must be ever so careful as to those that are preaching what they think is the Gospel, but is really not. Remember all it takes is a teaspoon of rat poisoning to kill you. Paul said it like this, “In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, when ye are gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus Christ, 5 To deliver such an one unto Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved in the day of the Lord Jesus. 6 Your glorying is not good. Know ye not that a little leaven leaveneth the whole lump (1 Cor. 5:1)? Jude says of those bringing in the poisonous doctrine and sinful practices, “For certain men have crept in unnoticed.” This is a scary thing when the church cannot notice the wolves in sheep clothing come to devour the sheep. We are to contend, speak for the Gospel and we have the mandate to speak against the deceptive messages that some have to preached which are false gospels. Does this mean that we are to argue with people? Paul wrote to Timothy, “But foolish and unlearned questions avoid, knowing that they do gender strifes. 24 And the servant of the Lord must not strive; but be gentle unto all men, apt to teach, patient﻿ ﻿, 25 In meekness instructing those that oppose themselves; if God peradventure will give them repentance to the acknowledging of the truth; 26 And that they may recover themselves out of the snare of the devil, who are taken captive by him at his will (2 Tim 2:23 -25). “You must teach what is in accord with sound doctrine (Titus 2:1),” as you “Watch your life and doctrine closely. Persevere in them, because if you do, you will save both yourself and your hearers (2 Tim4:16).” This is why we are instructed to, “2Ti 4:2 Preach the Word; be prepared in season and out of season; correct, rebuke and encourage—with great patience and careful instruction. 2Ti 4:3 For the time will come when men will not put up with sound doctrine. Instead, to suit their own desires, they will gather around them a great number of teachers to say what their itching ears want to hear (2 Tim 4:2, 3).” Saints, we must be diligent to preach the Word in and out of season. When you share the gospel with others, be diligent to make sure that the gospel that you hear, and share with others is truly the Gospel according to Jesus Christ, for no others “gospel” can transform a life to become like the person of Jesus Christ. Take time to go through the Gospel this week and read the very words of Jesus Christ and examine how you might apply what God reveals to you through them in your life.

Until the nets are filled…Blessing, Pastor Phil <><

For more “false gospel preachers, Check out http://www.pinpointevangelism.com/ for many preachers that preach false gospels.

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Ephesians 1:7, “In Him we have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of sins, according to the riches of His grace”


Of late I have been thinking about the saving grace of our Lord Jesus and I am constantly amazed at what He has done for a wretched man like me and I am very thankful to Him for what He has done.


There are some truths that continue to humble me about the saving grace and here is the biggest one, Jesus did not suffer and die on the cross because man was worth saving, He suffered and died on the cross because He was worthy to save. No one’s sacrifice was worthy to satisfy the demand of the law which was death


The Greek. word translated “redeemed” was often used to speak of buying a slave’s or debtor’s freedom. Christ’s death, because it was a death of substitution for sin, satisfied God’s justice and exhausted His wrath toward His elect, so that Christ actually purchased believers from slavery to sin and from the sentence of eternal death. For a broken law to be satisfied a blood sacrifice was required and Leviticus 17:11 tells us that, “The life of the flesh is in the blood” and if a life sheds blood, there is no more life left hence death. That is what the law does; it demands a blood sacrifice for it to be satisfied. Ezekiel 18:20, “The soul that sins shall die”, Romans 6:23, “for the wages of sin is death…”

Thank God for His saving plan, even when we were not worth saving (redeeming), He saved (redeemed) us through His blood. Ephesians 1:7 redemption through His blood. The term used here relates to paying the required ransom to God for the release of a person from bondage. Christ’s sacrifice on the cross paid that price for every elect person enslaved by sin, buying them out of the slave market of iniquity. The price of redemption was death . Now only saving faith unlocks the door of the prison where the law keeps men bound, kept under guard by the law. Paul personifies the law as a jailer of guilty, condemned sinners, ON DEATH ROW awaiting God’s judgment (Rom. 6:23). Faith in Christ alone releases (redeems) people from the death row of bondage to law.


We therefore do not accept Him as many use this terminology in reference to being saved by saying “I have accepted Jesus”, No, He accepts us and we in turn receive His acceptance. We will not enter into heaven primarily because we have accepted Christ, we will enter into heaven because God has accepted us through His Son Jesus. A certain preacher, Paul Washer in one of his preaching gave this analogy, if for example I went to White House, I will not be accepted into White House because I know President George W. Bush, I can only be accepted into White House because he knows me and he has invited me. How then can this also apply to the unsaved, we share the gospel with them and “we don’t tell people they are saved, we tell them how they can be saved, God tells them they are saved” Paul Washer

Christ has redeemed us from the curse of the law and now His REDEMPTION BRINGS IN THE LIMITLESS GRACE OF GOD.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: How Big is Your God? Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

I have a journal called Big Time Prayers for a Big time God. The title is so fitting for the character of God, yet it is not a character trait that most use to describe God, BIG. A little boy is told that the heater bars on a stove are hot and will burn his hand. He believes his parents cognitively. One day while mom is cooking, the little boy is enameled by the glowing colors of the stoves heater bars and reaches out to touch them, as something most little boys have done before. As soon as he touches the heater bars he no longer believes they are hot, HE now KNOWS they are hot. His experience brought him from the realm of cognitive belief, into experiential knowledge. With the pain of the burn, and the smell of his little burnt finger, this boy heard the echo of his parents loud and clear.

That’s what happened to Gideon in Judges chapter 6. Gideon is called by God while he is threshing wheat in the wine press in order to save it from the Medianites. As Gideon is doing this, he receives the call of God upon his life as God calls him “Mighty Warrior.” What a thing to be called by God. What an ironic title for a man with such a timid record. Gideon himself even challenged the validity of such words of himself. Gideon proclaimed that he was from the weakest family, and that he himself was the weakest one of his own family. He felt least qualified for the job. But it is just like our BIG GOD, to use the weak things of this world. God assures Gideon, “I will be with you, and you will strike down ALL the Midianites together.” WOW, He hadn’t really done anything for God yet, but God saw Gideon threshing the Midianites, the way he was threshing the wheat.

God tells Gideon to break down the altar to the false god of Baal, his fathers altar. What Gideon is going to go against his earthly father, the king? Yes, he did for the purposes of his Heavenly Father, The KING of kings!

Gideon builds the altar and proclaims at the altar, Jehovah Shalom, “The Lord is my Peace.” Why, because experientially he saw the angel of God face to face and did not die, but rather peace was the fruit that resulted. Gideon had an EXPERIENCE with our BIG GOD!

Then Gideon does his tests of the Lord’s will with the fleeces, and then after all that God goes and cuts his army from 32,000 men, to 10,000 and then to only 300! Why, because God was going to show Himself BIG! The story goes, as Gideon with 300 gains a BIG victory, because he had a BIG GOD, our GOD as His commanding officer.

What can you point to experientially lately, that you can perhaps appreciate as an attribute of God? BIG perhaps sounds too common for our great God, but yet BIG is so fitting for Him simultaneously. Gideon was called “Mighty Warrior,” what is God calling you experientially lately? God used Gideon to defeat the Midianites, after Gideon’s perception of himself was defeated, what is God calling you to defeat, or gain victory in that He is waiting for you to go in His power and take the land? How BIG is God to you!?!?

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Exodus 11:21-23, “…But all the children of Israel had light in their dwellings”

We have all been allowed an awesome opportunity to affect our surrounding. One thing I’m constantly reminded of is the fact that I am saved by grace and not by works. Eph 2:2&8, “It’s by grace you have been saved through faith, and not of yourselves; it’s the gift of God, not of works, lest anyone should boast”. This verse alone teaches me a lot of things as to how when I was lost, it’s not what I did that made me be accepted by Christ but what He did for me on the cross. When I understand this then I am reminded that there is nothing good in me but Christ as when I got saved nothing in me changed only my spirit and so this enables me to understand that someone somewhere has a chance to come to the Lord. All I got to do is put my light on top of the table that they may see the light of Christ in me.

Gal 2:20, “I am crucified with Christ, nevertheless I live but not I but Christ lives inside of me; the life that I now live in the flesh, I live by faith”. Once again we see that when we got saved, Christ took over, I have no reason to boast about anything, I am not better than any unbelievers. If we look in the book of Exodus, we see what had been happening in the land of Egypt as the children of Israel were afflicted, we see God coming to their rescue not to protect the Israelites because they were better than the Egyptians, but because they were His people. I pray that we will never forget that we are blessed, protected, cared for not because we are better but because we are His people and He has favored us. God gives grace to His followers not based on merit but His loving Kindness.

We see that darkness is the ninth plague being introduced in the land of Egypt, if you read from the time when the plagues started in Egypt, the children of Israel were also in the land only that, down in Goshen where they were, God had put a hedge of protection around them that none of the plagues affected them. When the ninth plague was executed, it affected the land for three days. Now this was no ordinary darkness, this was a huge one for it was dark in the day and at night and darkness was so thick that people could not see each other for those three days. The bible gives us a glimpse of how it was in Goshen and that is, the children of Israel had light in their dwellings. Weird things happen in the darkness, but God allows you to be in the light and darkness has no choice but surrender. Fear comes in the dark, going towards the wrong direction can be a result that you are not seeing the way, many bad things happen in darkness but when we are all in the light, we are at a better place. We are living in a world full of darkness that’s why we hear rapes, murder, kidnapping, immorality, divorce and many crazy things happening but thank God for Jesus, the light of the world. He says, John 9:5, “As long as I am in the world, I am the light of the world”, He being in us causes us to shine.

2Cor 6:17, “Therefore come out from among them and be separate, says the Lord”, The children of Israel were to live a separate life allowing God to come to their rescue when they needed Him the most and once again living this separate life was not to make them any better than the Egyptians but this was to allow the Egyptians to see that they were different and what made a difference in their lives was God Himself. We need to separate and allow the light of Christ to shine in our little Goshen that many may see the Christ inside of us. This goes about our talk, what we listen to, what we watch, what we associate ourselves with, places we go to and the rest. We all need to examine our ways and see if we are allowing something to put off the light we have been given. Let’s be like the five wise virgins who had their light on all the time that when the groom showed up, they were found ready. What is your little Goshen this morning, it could be your office, cube, apartment, your car, you name it. Your cube could be a light house when your surrounding is clouded with darkness. I believe that the moment people begin to see the light, they may desire to know what lights you up, so let your light shine before men, put it where it can be seen not to impress but for someone to know that Jesus is the Light of the world which is in darkness.

Thanks
Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Exodus 24:1-18, “Then the Lord said to Moses, “Come up to Me on the mountain and be there; and I will give you tablets of stone, and the law and commandments which I have written, that you may teach them”.

It is a good thing to escape at times from the daily pressures to spend time with the Lord. A time of refreshing in the presence of the Lord. A time to forget about everything that has been bringing you down and meditate on the word of God. Being busy many times rob us opportunity to pray or read the bible like we should. Martin Luther said, “I have so much to do today that I have to spend the first two hours in prayer” (paraphrased). What a way to look and face the day, so much to do but first spend the first few hours in prayers. We many times change it to, “I have so much to do today that I have no time to pray at all“. It’s like you have a tree to chop down, how fast it comes down will depend on the tool you are using and how sharp it is. For Martin Luther, he had so many trees to chop down that he needed two hours of sharpening his tools through prayer. Close out everything, enter into your closet, into the inner courts and sharpen all the tools you need to get the job done everyday.

Moses had been called by God to the mountain one time. This means for a time he will escape dealing with murmuring and complaining people. Away from the people who looked up to him with expectations and questions. I believe Moses needed some time to rest and recuperate with the greatest thing, time in the presence of the Lord. In as much as it’s time to get a way, he is going up to meet the Lord. Vs 16, “Now the glory of the Lord rested on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it for six days“. What first runs through my mind is the word “GLORY”. Glory is Majestic beauty and splendor. This is the best definition I could get to describe the glory of the Lord. Who wants to stay away from His glory? Here is Moses at the mountain; he is engulfed in the mist of the glory of the Lord covered with cloud. Everything around him looks beautiful and splendid, he can smell the fragrance of the glory. He has never seen anything like this anywhere in the world after all they are in the dessert. The scorch of heat, dust, sweat is what he always experienced but now he finds himself in the mist something one cannot describe. For six days he is locked in. “And on the seventh day He called to Moses out of the mist of the cloud”. This is like going past the gates of praise right into the sanctuary where he could seek God face to face. What an experience that I desire even more, Psalm 91:1, “He that dwells in the secret of the Most high shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty“ Psalm 91:14, “Because he has set his love upon ME, therefore I will deliver him, I will set him on high, because he has known My name“. This was Moses’ experience and this too can be ours if we truly seek it. For forty days and forty nights, Moses was away from all the pressures of the earth. I can’t imagine him thinking of where he came from.

In Exodus 32:7, “And the Lord said to Moses, “Go, get down! for your people whom you brought out of the land of Egypt have corrupted themselves“. All these time he has been up there with the Lord, learning, being given instructions, engulfed in the presence of God, meanwhile back in down where he came from, people are going a stray. God sends him back to where he came from. I believe real ministry starts when you have left the presence of the Lord to exercise what you have learnt before Him. In as much as I would love to spend every time in His presence, I have work to do. Many (especially unsaved) have not reached that level yet and my work and your work is to teach them God’s ways that they too may experience what we do when we are in the presence of the Lord. Moses who had an opportunity to be in His presence forever came back to the people with God’s commandments which was to teach them the things the Lord showed him. It’s tough to come back and start dealing with things you escaped for a while but it is necessary. Your coming and my coming up the mountain was to get us ready for the for work. In Psalm 51 after David asked for forgiveness, his next move was to teach transgressors God’s ways. After Peter had a vision from the Lord at his resting time, he was sent to Cornelius’ house to preach to them. It was tough for him because he considered them unclean or unfit but that is the place God sent him.

The thing about being away and coming back is, going away gives you time to be refreshed in the Lord, coming back allows you to now face what sent you away in the first place. Trials, temptations, whatever you got convicted of while you were away now awaits you to deal with them, your work is to set your house in order. Attitude adjustment, revived, strengthened, encouraged, established, your face glowing from having met the Lord. Thank God for those times alone in His presence. Thanks be to Him for brining us up to where He wants to reach out to us and later sends us to continue with the work He started in our lives. You may have prayed, “Father take me away from this world to be with you forever”, Jesus prays, “Father keep them in this world, only keep them away from the wicked one“. Always desire to be sharpened to do His work. Blessings Evans

Thanks
Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Deut 1:37, “The Lord was angry with me for your sakes, saying even you shall not go in there”

In Exodus 17:6, Moses is leading the children of Israel from the land of Egypt moving towards the promise land. He is leading a people who have not stopped complaining from day one even up to this every moment. Many times God wanted to kill the children of Israel because of their complains and murmuring but Moses kept on pleading with God. On this day in Exodus 17, the people had just complained as usual about something they were lacking. Already God had given them everything they cried for and this time they needed water and instead of looking to God, they begin to reflect on how they would have been satisfied in Egypt. How possible it is that You can be heading to the promise land while Egypt could still be present in your life. Every time you face a tough situation, your first place to look at Egypt, a place come from. You can be out of Egypt but Egypt may not be out of you. Egypt represents the world where when we got saved, a deliverer Moses (Holy Spirit) came to lead us out of bondage but in the process of being led, one’s eyes were still fixed on Egypt. Egypt was a land of less than enough, then brought into the wilderness was a land of just enough and God was bringing them to a land of more than enough. We have to reach at a place of not always operating in the land of just enough to which the provision is always by miracle to a land of more than enough, a land of blessings. I refuse to live by miracles everyday, yes the miracles are good for miracles are to get me from point A to point B but living under blessings is always having the provision.

So the people complained and God told Moses in Exodus 17:6, “Behold, I stand before thee there upon the rock of Horeb; and thou shall smite the rock, and there shall come water out of it, that the people may drink. And Moses did so in the sight of the elders of Israel” This is what the Lord chose for this time and that was for Moses to hit the rock for water come out. Now let’s look at another time the Lord wanted to provide water to the children of Israel in Numbers 20:8, “Take thy rod, and gather thou the assembly together, thou, and Aaron thy brother, and speak unto the rock before their eyes; and it shall give thee forth water, and thou shall bring forth to them water out of the rock”. So we see one instant Moses is asked to strike the rock and another instant he is asked to speak to the rock. God can do anything at any time using any method He chooses, He is God. Don’t expect Him to move the same way He moved the first time, He is not limited to our planning. When you expect the Lord to come through the door, don’t be surprised if He comes in through the window.

Amazing thing about the whole story with the children of Israel is every time they complained and God felt like wiping them out, Moses defended them but at one point Moses got fed up with their cry, complain and murmur and so He took the word of the Lord but began to speak to the people in an anger and instead of obeying the Lord, his anger caused him to strike the rock twice instead of speaking to it .Num 20:11, “And Moses lifted up his hand, and with his rod he smote the rock twice”. Yes the Lord gave the children of Israel water even though Moses disobeyed but Moses was left to suffer the consequences. Eph 4:26, “Be ye angry, and sin not: let not the sun go down upon your wrath”. It’s very easy to get angry and do something you will regret and the enemy knows how to bring people your way that will try and push you to anger. Moses was on the verge of entering the promise land but because of his anger that led him to disobey God caused him the land he had waited to see for 40 years. Be careful about how you deal with things under anger and frustrations for you could be killing what the Lord had been planning to do in your life from day one. As we have seen in the book of Ephesians, “be angry and sin not” is very true for the enemy will always look for ways to make you stumble and fall and as Moses tells us in Deut 1:37, “The Lord was angry with me for your sakes, saying even you shall not go in there”, people pushed him to the limit, don’t allow people and situations push you to the limit for you could do something you will regret for a long time. Be cool, be still, calm yourself, don’t fight fire with fire but be the fire extinguisher, don’t give the enemy an inch for he will want the whole thing, be angry if you must but don’t let it cause you to sin. Anger is one letter short for DANGER.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Beware of False Teachers (Part 2) by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

7﻿ For ﻿﻿many deceivers have gone out into the world ﻿who do not confess Jesus Christ as coming in the flesh. ﻿This is a deceiver and an antichrist. ﻿8﻿ ﻿Look to yourselves, ﻿﻿that ﻿we do not lose those things we worked for, but that ﻿﻿we may receive a full reward. ﻿9﻿ ﻿Whoever ﻿﻿transgresses and does not abide in the doctrine of Christ does not have God. He who abides in the doctrine of Christ has both the Father and the Son. ﻿10﻿ If anyone comes to you and ﻿﻿does not bring this doctrine, do not receive him into your house nor greet him; ﻿11﻿ for he who greets him shares in his evil deeds. (2 John 7 – 11)

In part 1 of this series, Beware of False Teachers we examined Peter’s warning of false teachers spoke of why the unbiblical doctrine of some is such a dangerous poison among those in the Church. Not only did Peter give these warnings, but the Apostle John did as well. There are some that are preaching and confessing that Jesus Christ did not come in the flesh. Now there are many preachers out there that would certainly fit into this category, but a group that is even more subtle and equally as dangerous is the preachers and groups that preach that Jesus did come in the flesh, but they preach a different Jesus other than then One in the Scriptures. Jesus said, concerning the Judgment Day, “Many will say to Me in that day, ‘Lord, Lord, have we ﻿﻿not prophesied in Your name, cast out demons in Your name, and done many wonders in Your name?’ ﻿23﻿ And ﻿﻿then I will declare to them, ‘I never knew you; ﻿﻿depart from Me, you who practice lawlessness!’ Also in Matt 7:13, “Enter by the narrow gate; for wide is the gate and broad is the way that leads to destruction, and there are many who go in by it.” It should not be a surprise that John writes, ﻿ For ﻿﻿many deceivers have gone out into the world who do not confess Jesus Christ as coming in the flesh… There are so many deceivers in our world, and there is something we must listen for to discern who is true and who is false. Here it is, “Whoever ﻿transgresses and does not abide in the doctrine of Christ does not have God. He who abides in the doctrine of Christ has both the Father and the Son.” It is crucial that one abide in the doctrine of Christ. John MacArthur writes, A failure to be faithful to the fundamental, sound doctrines of the faith (a proper view of the person and work of Christ, love, obedience) marks a person as having never been born again (1 John 2:23; 3:6–10; 4:20,21; 5:1–3). The word “abide” has the idea of constant adherence and warns that these fundamentals are not open to change or subject to the latest trends or philosophical fads.” We must abide in the doctrine (teaching) of Jesus Christ, it is crucial for us to be in the Word of God daily, not every other day, or every once in a while. There are many heretics preaching at this time. There are those that deny the Infallibility of Scripture; the denial of Substitutionary Atonement; etc.) A heretic is one who therefore denies the Faith and cannot be a true Christian (2 Peter 2-3). The use of the term should be reserved for clear cases (like ‘Bishop’ John Spong; Kenneth Copeland; Benny Hinn; the Jehovah’s Witnesses; the Mormons; etc.)


Error is a departure from Biblical Truth, but generally one not so serious as to deny the Faith. Peter was in error when Paul rebuked him openly to his face, but Peter was not a heretic. Errors can be major and serious (bordering right on heresy – like denial of eternal punishment), through to minor (‘how many angels are there in heaven’ stuff). They usually have negative impacts on practice and other doctrines. Such a person who embraces such things is in error (or even in serious error), but should be rebuked/challenged/dialogued with, lovingly as a brother (1 Corinthians 11:19; 2 Corinthians 10:1; Hebrews 5:11-14) until their conscience is changed or our own error exposed.


Essentially, this is one of the reasons why we need the Body/Church (assuming it holds to the Word Alone doctrine). Error does not normally refer to such things as alcohol, movies or other questions of Christian liberty where there can be diversity/liberty of application within basic principles – unless one turns their principles into laws and tries to impose it on other’s consciences (cf Romans 14). Hence – someone who promotes the prosperity teaching but is otherwise ‘sound’ is in serious error but not a heretic. (Indeed ‘denominations’ have arisen to allow people with differences of conscience to worship the way they believe while still recognizing others as true Christians (unlike Rome who has taught that “outside the [Roman] church there is no salvation”).


These are some of the basic distinctions that can be made between Heresy and Error, and are essential when dealing with issues of discernment and deception in the Church.

Brothers and sisters, please be sure to abide in the doctrine of Christ, by reading, and studying His Word, the Words of truth daily and of course obeying what you read. You will see too that God’s Word is sure, and that God will NEVER let you down as you abide in Him, His Son, His Spirit, His Word, and in His Will.

Until the nets are filled…Blessing, Pastor Phil <><

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Psalm 94:17-19, “Unless the Lord had been my help, My soul would soon have settled in silence”

You could be facing something that is really tearing you apart. There are days everyone is so overwhelmed by things that you just can’t take it no more. Frustrations have pushed you to the edge that how to deal with them are nearly impossible. You have tried to strengthen yourself but you find yourself back to worrying, helpless and confused. Tears roll down your cheeks and you just can’t help stop it. You wish that the people you love are around to help you overcome what you have to deal with but still that doesn’t happen. What do you do? I have been there, felt it, wanted to run away, cried myself to sleep but in all I learnt more about the one who knows my down sitting and my uprising, the one who is familiar with my ways. He knows when I am so weak and just need to stop and cry.

It’s easy to see someone stand strong as a soldier but like a song goes, “they don’t know that I would go running home when I fall down, they don’t know who picks me up when no one is around, I drop my sword and cry for just a while, cause deep inside this armor, the warrior is a child“. Many people tend to see the armor but let them take a deeper look and see that inside that armor, the person in it has the heart of a child. A heart that can melt, be broken, be scared but that is okay because it teaches you more on who to depend on. God does bring us to those seasons so that our confidence is not in any man but in Him.

Psalm 94:17, “Unless the Lord had been my help, My soul would have settled in silence“, Had it not been for the Lord’s help, whatever I do or what other people have done would have either failed or just became a temporary solution to my problem. In a case like this, who can give peace apart from God? Many times it’s the peace that is needed to endure. If you had peace inside, even if the situation did not change, adapting to it made you comfortable. Comfort does not mean you are okay with but it means you handle it and survive without it pulling you down. God helps us so that we are at peace because His peace surpasses all human understanding. The bible says in Philippians 4:7, “And the peace OF God…”, it’s the peace that originates from above, no one can give it but Him.

Vs. 18, “If I say, “My foot slips,” Your mercy, O Lord, will hold me up“. Mercy and grace tends to work together, when you have peace inside, God gives the grace to endure. Paul after praying three times for something to be removed, God’s word came to him in 2Corinthians 12:9, “And He said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, My strength is made perfect in weakness”. What Paul needed the most was not to get out of the trouble but the grace to endure and this was his response 2Corinthians 12:9, “…Therefore most gladly I will rather boast in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may rest upon me. vs. 10, “Therefore I take please in infirmities, in reproaches, in needs, in persecution, in distress, for Christ sake. For when I am weak, then I am strong. When he was weak, Christ in Him was strong and Christ made him strong. See Christ mercy and grace did hold Paul up and that changed the way he responded to his situation.

Psalm 94:19, “In the multitude of my anxieties within me, Your comfort delight my soul“. What a way to identify all that is within you and have the Lord’s comfort delight your soul to the extent that what should bother you, he has placed it under His control, what brings tears of sorrows in your eyes has been changed to bring tears of joy for you know who holds today, tomorrow and the future. What should frustrate you, He has given you peace to ride it out. Sooner or later, you are taught more on how to encourage yourself like Paul and David that even if there is no one around, you can encourage yourself in the Lord. When God has taught you more of it, don’t be surprised if He brings people your way who will need the same encouragement because His words made a difference in your life. Blessings Evans

Thanks
Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Psalm 119:105, “Thy word is a lamp unto my feet and a light unto my path”

It’s good to know the word and more so to know the God of the word, He is the word Himself. The Gospel of John 1:1 takes us back to the origin to understand how the word of God is connected to Jesus. In the beginning was the word and the word was with God and the word was God, everything was created by the word and were it not for God, nothing that has been created could have been created. As you continue to read down the same chapter, you will see how the word was made flesh and dwelt among us and we beheld the glory of the Son of God. John tells us that Jesus existed from the beginning, contrary to what some people believe.

The word is a lamp unto our feet and a light unto our path. We read the word with understanding. Jesus said, John 14:6, “I am the way, the truth and the life, no man comes to the Father but by me“, already Jesus has stated clearly that He is the way and knowing that He is the word Himself He is the one who will guide us through the paths of life.

Remember how God came through for the Israelites when they faced hard times as they were journeying to the promise land, God went before them by day as a cloud of wind and by night as a pillar of fire. We know how fire provides light and also fire consumes anything on its path, and by this I believe God meant that He will not just shine their way but also clear their path the reason for a lamp unto your feet and a light unto your path.

The more we know the word and the God of the word, the more we can be stirred up in the right direction. Psalm 37:23, “The good steps of a righteous man are ordered of the Lord, He delights in his ways and whichever way he turns, he will prosper”. I do struggle getting the word inside, meditating on it and memorizing it but I know that the more I do what I struggle with, the more I can see my way clearly because getting hold of the word means getting hold of the One who knows the way. People who do not know and are unsure of the way tend to go in circles wasting time and getting lost again and again, finding themselves in wrong places. They are not progressing and growing because they are stuck in the same place. When we are confident who is leading the way, though we may go through the valleys of the shadow of death, we will not fear evil for He knows the way and we are following.

How much of the word is a lamp unto your feet and a light unto your path. Are we reading the word without fail, let me go a step forward, are we STUDYING the word or are we waiting for Sunday morning for the word to be preached? Are we memorizing the word and applying them in our lives? and are we checking the words we hear from preaching, teachings and devotions to prove they are written and are applied correctly? Even in my weakness I desire to know the word and the God of the word. Psalm 86:11 “Teach me your ways oh Lord and I will walk in your truth, unite my heart to fear our name”, Psalm 25:4&5, “show me your ways O Lord, teach me your paths. Lead me in your truth and teach me, For you are the God of my salvation; on You I wait all the day, Psalm 119:89, “Forever O Lord thy word is settled in heaven. Find the word!!!!!!

PS: some of you have emailed me and I haven’t had a chance to respond back, 4th quarter is taking a toll on me so please be patient with me, I will respond.

Thanks
Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Matt 14:22-32, “…Lord, if it is You, command me to come to You on water…”

Moving people are not stagnant people. Moving people always have new experiences because they are not stationed in one place. Moving people will always encounter with change in situations, circumstance and in their personal lives. When you think you finally got it, God will move something in your life or move you again you may constantly depend on Him. Who would need God if they had everything figured out? I thank God I don’t have everything figured out.

Four things to learn from the story of Peter walking on water. The first thing is VISION. Jesus had asked the disciples to cross over to the other side of the sea while Jesus sent home the people who came to listen to Him preach. While the disciples were crossing, their rose a great wind that tossed the ship and they could not navigate it properly. In the midst of panic and confusion, Jesus appears at a distance and their immediate response was that they had seen a ghost, as they had never seen Him walk on water. Jesus reveals Himself without changing the situation and Peter takes a closer look at Him and gets a vision. Every believer needs to have a vision, something to look a head for, something you desire to accomplish with God’s help in the midst of storm of life. The bible says that “where there is no vision people perish, Pro 29:18”. Vision starts life into something dead.

Having a vision in your life causes you to have a DESIRE; this is the second key. Well many people tend to use this line, “whatever the Lord decides for me, let it be”. Wait a minute; He has allowed us to present our desires in line with His will. Jesus’ desire was His wish for the cup of suffering to pass Him nevertheless He gave up His will for the Father’s. Mark 11:24, “What things so ever you desire….” This reminds us that we have desires and if our desires are confined within His will, God is faithful to make it happen. Desire could be a better position, a call in the ministry, your loved ones to be saved and many more are desires. But desires do not come about until you’ve visioned it or in other words you’ve seen something good at a distance and you desire it even before you receive it.

Desire progresses FAITH, this is interesting because if you read the story, it wasn’t Jesus idea for Peter to come, it was Peter’s idea as He had seen the Son of God walk on water and he understood his relationship to Him in the sense that if He could do it, then he (Peter) could because it’s not by might nor by power but by His Spirit says the Lord, Zech 4:6. He understood that if he was going to attempt the impossible, He had to have faith in God. His faith in Christ causes him to step out from the possible to the impossible. Faith tends to defy the laws of nature, as it does not depend on facts. The reason why he could step out of the boat boldly is because He had asked Jesus vs. 28. “ Lord, if it is You, command me to come to You on water”. He is telling the Lord exactly how he wants to come to Him and all he is asking for is the Lord’s approval. We can go before God with our desires, Him approving it is a sign of victory. Before David could engage himself in any battle, he asked for the Lord’s approval. The moment God approved, it was an indication of victory for the Lord was going to help him win. You need to initiate your desire to Him that He may act on it according to His will.

Heb 12:2, “looking unto Jesus the author and the finisher of our faith”. Next is FOCUS. It’s easy to begin something through vision to desire to faith, but it becomes difficult to keep focus till the end because of distractions on the way. Pride can be one; life’s storms can be another to mention a few. These things can be overwhelming to sink you in what you should be overcoming. As long as Peter’s focus was on Christ, everything was fine but the moment his eyes were withdrawn from the supernatural to the natural, he began to sink. Looking (focusing) unto Jesus the author and the finisher of our faith. He gives us more faith when our eyes are fixed on Him but if we loose track and begin to sink, we can call on Him to save us from sinking. Have a vision for your life, begin to desire what you see in the spirit, have faith that you have received them, keep you eyes on Him at all times, in every circumstance and every situation and you will make it.

Last point, Peter’s vision then desire then faith and finally focus was not leading him away from Jesus as anything that the Lord is doing in our lives should not draw us away from Him, it should bring us even closer to Him. Let anything that you are working towards bring you even closer to Him but if you begin to drift, stop and seek the Lord to show you how you can draw closer to Him.

Thanks
Evans

Jesus had asked the disciples to cross over to the other side of the sea while Jesus sent home the people who came to listen to Him preach. While the disciples were crossing, their rose a great wind that tossed the ship and they could not navigate it properly. In the midst of panic and confusion, Jesus appears at a distance and their immediate response was that they had seen a ghost, as they had never seen Him walk on water. Jesus reveals Himself without changing the situation and Peter takes a closer look at Him and gets a vision. Every believer needs to have a vision, something to look a head for, something you desire to accomplish with God’s help in the midst of storm of life. The bible says that “where there is no vision people perish, Pro 29:18”. Vision starts life into something dead.

Having a vision in your life causes you to have a DESIRE; this is the second key. Well many people tend to use this line, “whatever the Lord decides for me, let it be”. Wait a minute; He has allowed us to present our desires in line with His will. Jesus’ desire was His wish for the cup of suffering to pass Him nevertheless He gave up His will for the Father’s. Mark 11:24, “What things so ever you desire….” This reminds us that we have desires and if our desires are confined within His will, God is faithful to make it happen. Desire could be a better position, a call in the ministry, your loved ones to be saved and many more are desires. But desires do not come about until you’ve visioned it or in other words you’ve seen something good at a distance and you desire it even before you receive it.

Desire progresses FAITH, this is interesting because if you read the story, it wasn’t Jesus idea for Peter to come, it was Peter’s idea as He had seen the Son of God walk on water and he understood his relationship to Him in the sense that if He could do it, then he (Peter) could because it’s not by might nor by power but by His Spirit says the Lord, Zech 4:6. He understood that if he was going to attempt the impossible, He had to have faith in God. His faith in Christ causes him to step out from the possible to the impossible. Faith tends to defy the laws of nature, as it does not depend on facts. The reason why he could step out of the boat boldly is because He had asked Jesus vs. 28. “ Lord, if it is You, command me to come to You on water”. He is telling the Lord exactly how he wants to come to Him and all he is asking for is the Lord’s approval. We can go before God with our desires, Him approving it is a sign of victory. Before David could engage himself in any battle, he asked for the Lord’s approval. The moment God approved, it was an indication of victory for the Lord was going to help him win. You need to initiate your desire to Him that He may act on it according to His will.

Heb 12:2, “looking unto Jesus the author and the finisher of our faith”. Next is FOCUS. It’s easy to begin something through vision to desire to faith, but it becomes difficult to keep focus till the end because of distractions on the way. Pride can be one; life’s storms can be another to mention a few. These things can be overwhelming to sink you in what you should be overcoming. As long as Peter’s focus was on Christ, everything was fine but the moment his eyes were withdrawn from the supernatural to the natural, he began to sink. Looking (focusing) unto Jesus the author and the finisher of our faith. He gives us more faith when our eyes are fixed on Him but if we loose track and begin to sink, we can call on Him to save us from sinking. Have a vision for your life, begin to desire what you see in the spirit, have faith that you have received them, keep you eyes on Him at all times, in every circumstance and every situation and you will make it.

Last point, Peter’s vision then desire then faith and finally focus was not leading him away from Jesus as anything that the Lord is doing in our lives should not draw us away from Him, it should bring us even closer to Him. Let anything that you are working towards bring you even closer to Him but if you begin to drift, stop and seek the Lord to show you how you can draw closer to Him.

Thanks
Evans

Good morning,
“Blessed is he who does not walk in the counsel of the wicked, or stand in the way of the sinners ,sit in the seat of the mockers” Psalms 1 : 1

As we are all aware, the beginning of anything is the thought. First this thought manifests itself in action, which later turns into a habit. This habit becomes a trait/character which finally leads to destiny-either hell or heaven.

There are three verbs mentioned in the above verse –walk, stand and sit, three nouns-counsel, way and seat and three categories of people -wicked /evil/corrupt/immoral/ heinous/atrocious…mock/counterfeit/fraudulent/sinner/transgressor/offender/adulterer/culprit..

When we begin our life’s journey adhering to the counsel/ guidance /information/caution/instruction/opinion/recommendation of our Master teacher, walk according to His counsel, we will always be victorious…If we have already obtained caution from the Lord, we can avoid danger which was otherwise unknown….Isaiah 9:6 speaks of the Lord as the wonderful counselor…Since He is the storehouse of wisdom and knowledge, He is the matchless and expert counselor… Whose counsel are we taking? These days, many so called believers are also running after enchanters/wizards/witches/sorceress/magicians for knowing their future, for getting some counseling…But are we looking to the Lord for counsel? We had earlier seen that Haman was delighted to hear the evil counsel of his wife and officials, which later resulted in his own ruin…Rehoboam, as seen in 2 Chronicles 10:14 took counsel of his young friends and created terrible trouble for himself.. God will counsel, provided we hear Him…In my life, there were some serious incidents when the Lord Himself guided me and advised the course of action…

Stand literally means determination/ effort taken. We all sing the song ”Standing on the promises of God” Yes, we need to stand/base /position ourselves on the unchanging promises/covenants/assurance/words of God …as they are trustworthy …If we do not take a stand, we are prone to succumb and fall into temptation or slide back into sin or entangled in this dangerous world…
Have we taken a stand to be holy, irrespective of whatever trial or test arises. Joseph a man in the Bible is a classic example who took a stand to be holy and in the process preferred running away from the princely mansion in order to be away from sin and landed into a dungeon …But he never compromised in his stand/decision…People find excuses for their compromise saying that there was no other way out. But Jesus says “I am the WAY, the truth and the life” …..Yes, we can proceed in this most assured WAY to be peaceful for ever and ever. As we know where this way leads to –the eternal abode

People today love to sit with mockers, friends who are involved in coarse joking /indecent/vulgar/lowbred acts. Maybe we do not do it but accompany those who are involved in such sort of lewd/depraved/lustful chats/conversation …Where are we sitting? God wants us to be mindful of our seat, the place we sit /lie/relax/repose/dwell, the seat/location/position which we occupy…Does it lead to the glory of God. If we resist sitting with mockers, God is promising us to grant us to sit with Him …What a great privilege as mentioned in Revelation 3:21 to be seated with the Almighty .”To him who overcomes, I will give the right to sit with me on my THRONE”.…Yes we usually tend to make friends and finally invite them home, God loves to make us his friends, if we adhere to His counsel, walk in His way and we will be invited to His home to sit on His throne…and this blessing is forever and ever…for eternity,
by Sarah Susan

title.rendered: Beware of False teachers (Part 1), by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,
1 But there were false prophets also among the people, even as there shall be false teachers among you, who privily shall bring in damnable heresies, even denying the Lord that bought them, and bring upon themselves swift destruction. 2 And many shall follow their pernicious ways﻿﻿; by reason of whom the way of truth shall be evil spoken of. 2 Peter 2:1-2

Anyone that has watched a magician or an illusionist knows that the hand can appear to be quicker than the eye. Many illusionists cause one to look in one direction while the illusionist does something in another direction. Illusionist show things that are false hiding what things are true. Peter writes that false teachers are among you and they shall bring damnable heresies, even denying the Lord that bought them and bring them and bring upon themselves swift destruction. Peter tells us:

There are teachers among you now, at this time that are false. These false teachers may be heard on the radio, seen and heard on television, they have authored of books, and of course some preach in churches and or stadiums. Perhaps you listen to some of these false teachers. One must realize that just because a preacher or teacher is popular that does not automatically connote that the preacher is biblical. Hitler was popular, but certainly not a man of integrity, and certainly did not preach truth, using Evolution to substantiate his racial superiority jargon. If a preacher can get a large following, this too does not equate a biblical source in the preacher. Any music celebrity can also gain a large following, can also pack a stadium or concert hall full of people that will scream their name, buy their products, and wear their apparel. The church is not popularity contest. Jesus choose twelve, and one was lost, he did not have a large following in this light, but those that followed him learning to be fishers of men.

How can one recognize a false teacher? Peter answers this question by saying one can recognize a false teacher by realizing the damnable heresies, even denying the Lord bought them and bring upon themselves swift destruction. Do the preachers you listen to preach damnable heresies. Here are some popular heresies among the professing Christian preachers today:

1. There is another way to heaven other than Jesus

2. People are basically good (moral) in their heart

3. God would never send anyone to Hell

4. My God would never create Hell

5. The trinity does not exist

6. One can be a “good” Muslim, Mormon, Buddhist, Hindu, etc… and still make it to heaven

Many deny this payment that Christ paid on the cross, choosing to put faith in ones “good works” rather than on the finished work of Jesus Christ on the cross. Peter said that swift destruction would come upon them. Remember that judgment delayed (in our estimation) is not judgment denied. Please, be very careful about the preachers and teachers that you are listening to whether via TV, radio, reading a book or magazine, etc…. Evans and I would be open for you all to examine the messages that we share to be sure that we are staying biblically accurate. We can accidentally be in error. Let 1 Timothy 3:16 and 2 Timothy 2:15 be your guide as you beware of false teachers.

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: Teaching On Doctrine Essentials, Part 4, by John F. MacArthur (Complied by Evans Olang)

content.rendered:
Good morning,

It has not been my purpose here to attempt to give an exhaustive list of fundamental doctrines. Such a task is beyond the scope of this article. Furthermore, the attempt to precisely identify and number such a list of doctrines would be an extremely difficult thing to do. However, a reasonable list of fundamentals would necessarily begin with these doctrines explicitly identified in Scripture as non-negotiable: the absolute authority of Scripture over tradition (sola Scriptura), justification by faith alone (sola fide), the deity of Christ, and the Trinity.

But what are we to do with this understanding? First of all, we should resist any temptation to wield these doctrines like a judge’s gavel that consigns multitudes to eternal doom. We must not set ourselves up as judges of other people’s eternal fate.

On the other hand, we must recognize that those who have turned away from sound doctrine in matters essential to salvation are condemning themselves. “He who does not believe has been judged already” (John 3:18). Our passion ought to be to proclaim the fundamentals with clarity and precision, in order to turn people away from the darkness of error. We must confront head-on the blindness and unbelief that will be the reason multitudes will one day hear the Lord say, “I never knew you; depart from Me” (Matthew 7:23). Again, it must be stressed that those who act as if crucial doctrines were of no consequence only heap the false teacher’s guilt on themselves (2 John 11).

We have no right to pronounce a sentence of eternal doom against anyone (John 5:22). But by the same token, we have no business receiving just anyone into the communion and fellowship of the church. We should no more forge spiritual bonds with people whose religion is fundamentally in error than we would seek fellowship with those guilty of heinous sin. To do so is tantamount to the arrogance shown by the Corinthians, who refused to dismiss from their fellowship a man living in the grossest kind of sin (1 Corinthians 5:1-3).

We must also remember that serious error can be extremely subtle. False teachers don’t wear a sign proclaiming who they are. They disguise themselves as apostles of Christ (2 Corinthians 11:13). “And no wonder, for even Satan disguises himself as an angel of light. Therefore it is not surprising if his servants also disguise themselves as servants of righteousness” (vv. 14-15).

IN VIEW OF THE CURRENT HUNGER FOR ECUMENICAL COMPROMISE, NOTHING IS MORE DESPERATELY NEEDED IN THE CHURCH RIGHT NOW THAN A NEW MOVEMENT TO REEMPHASIZE THE FUNDAMENTAL ARTICLES OF THE FAITH.

Adapted from John F. MacArthur, Reckless Faith (Wheaton, IL: Crossway, 1997), pp. 108-17.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Teaching On Doctrine Essentials, Part 3, by John F. MacArthur (Complied by Evans Olang)

content.rendered:
Good morning,
IV. Every Doctrine We Are Forbidden to Deny Is Fundamental
Certain teachings of Scripture carry threats of damnation to those who deny them. Other ideas are expressly stated to be affirmed only by unbelievers. Such doctrines, obviously, involve fundamental articles of genuine Christianity.

The apostle John began his first epistle with a series of statements that establish key points of the doctrine of sin (hamartiology) as fundamental articles of faith. “If we say that we have fellowship with Him and yet walk in the darkness, we lie and do not practice the truth” (1:6). That condemns wanton antinomianism (the idea that Christians are under no law whatsoever) and makes some degree of doctrinal and moral enlightenment essential to true Christianity. A second statement rules out the humanistic notion that people are basically good: “If we say that we have no sin, we are deceiving ourselves, and the truth is not in us” (v. 8). And a third suggests that no true Christian would deny his or her own sinfulness: “If we say that we have not sinned, we make Him a liar, and His word is not in us” (v. 10).

First Corinthians 16:22 makes love for Christ a fundamental issue: “If anyone does not love the Lord, let him be accursed.” And a similar verse, 1 Corinthians 12:3, says that no one speaking by the Spirit of God can call Jesus accursed.

The truth of Jesus’ incarnation is also clearly designated a fundamental doctrine: “Every spirit that confesses that Jesus Christ has come in the flesh is from God; and every spirit that does not confess Jesus is not from God; and this is the spirit of the antichrist” (1 John 4:2-3). “For many deceivers have gone out into the world, those who do not acknowledge Jesus Christ as coming in the flesh. This is the deceiver and the antichrist” (2 John 7). Those verses by implication also condemn those who deny the Virgin Birth of our Lord, for if He was not virgin-born, He would be merely human, not eternal God come in the flesh.

And since those who twist and distort the Word of God are threatened with destruction (2 Peter 3:16), it is evident that both a lofty view of Scripture and a sound method of Bible interpretation (hermeneutics) are fundamental tenets of true Christianity.

V. The Fundamental Doctrines Are All Summed up in the Person and Work of Christ
Paul wrote, “No man can lay a foundation other than the one which is laid, which is Jesus Christ” (1 Corinthians 3:11). Christ Himself embodied or established every doctrine that is essential to genuine Christianity. Those who reject any of the cardinal doctrines of the faith worship a christ who is not the Christ of Scripture.

How are the fundamentals of the faith personified in Christ? With regard to the inspiration and authority of Scripture, He is the incarnate Word (John 1:1, 14). He upheld the written Word’s absolute authority (Matthew 5:18). Christ Himself established sola Scriptura as a fundamental doctrine when He upbraided the Pharisees for nullifying Scripture with their own traditions: “Rightly did Isaiah prophesy of you hypocrites, as it is written, ‘This people honors Me with their lips, but their heart is far away from Me. But in vain do they worship Me, teaching as doctrines the precepts of men.’ Neglecting the commandment of God, you hold to the tradition of men…. You nicely set aside the commandment of God in order to keep your tradition” (Mark 7:6-9). Our Lord had much to say about the authority and infallibility of the Word of God.

In the doctrine of justification by faith, it is Christ’s own perfect righteousness, imputed to the believer, that makes the pivotal difference between true biblical justification and the corrupted doctrine of Roman Catholicism and the cults. That is what Paul meant when he wrote, “Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to everyone who believes” (Romans 10:4). It is also why Paul wrote that Christ is become to us righteousness (1 Corinthians 1:30), and it is why Jeremiah called Him “The Lord our righteousness” (Jeremiah 23:6). The Lord Himself, Jesus Christ, is our righteousness (Jeremiah 33:16). That is the very essence of justification by faith alone, sola fide.

Of course, all the fundamental doctrines related to the incarnation–the Virgin Birth of Christ, His deity, His humanity, and His sinlessness–are part and parcel of who He is. To deny any of those doctrines is to attack Christ Himself.

The essential doctrines related to His work-His atoning death, His resurrection, and the reality of His miracles-are the very basis of the Gospel (cf. 1 Corinthians 15:1-4; Hebrews 2:3-4). Reject them and you nullify the heart of the Christian message.

The fundamentals of the faith are so closely identified with Christ that the apostle John used the expression “the teaching of Christ” as a kind of shorthand for the set of doctrines he regarded as fundamental. To him, these doctrines represented the difference between true Christianity and false religion.

That is why he wrote, “Anyone who goes too far and does not abide in the teaching of Christ, does not have God; the one who abides in the teaching, he has both the Father and the Son” (2 John 9). Far from encouraging union with those who denied the fundamental truths of the faith, John forbade any form of spiritual fellowship with or encouragement of such false religion (vv. 10-11).

Thanks
Evans
